This is a composite of NORMA RAE WEBSTER's life, glimpses of her early days, a burgeoning and a metamorphosis: She is seen as an infant, sitting in her bath ina galvanized tub, hair twisted into a kewpie-doll peak, beribboned. Norma at seven, front tooth out, a large grin splitting h face. At twelve in a bathing suit, a pigeon-toed stance, arms folded self-consciously across her chest. At fifteen, facing front, arrogant now, breasts jutting o hip cocked. At eighteen, her arm around a sailor's shoulder, wearing his hat at a rakish angle. At twenty on a front porch with a cluster of girls, Norma at the center, mouth black with too much lipstick, holdin a ukulele. At twenty-two, holding a bridal bouquet, wearing a floppy hat, perplexed, faintly forlorn, on the edge of the unkno At twenty-four, defiant, thumbing her nose at a sign read "Simpson's Secretarial School." At twenty-six, sitting with her back against a tree, twe young children tumbled in her lap, looking fond and frazz At twenty-eight, in a monkey-pert waitress!’ outfit, balancing a tray, ground lost. At thirty, a photographer's formal portrait, unguarded, beautiful, unfathomable. At thirty-two, mature, strong, with humor, without illusi

The place bursts on the SCREEN like a battlefield, full o a jolting, nerve-shattering din. In the enormous space, rows and rows of old WOODEN LOOMS ROAR like waterfalls an shake the floors with ceaseless trembling vibrations. The sound is deafening, the constant punishing, racketing mot disorienting. There are no windows, no sunlight, only blank, brick walls; it is a seasonless, timeless world in which men and women cannot hear themselves think, do not think. They are bound and shackled to the work.

Steam vents spew mist into every corner to keep the yarn hot and wet. Mosquito netting rises from the floor and disappears overhead in the high dark reaches toward the ceiling. There is a permanent haze everywhere made by lin coming off the rolls of terry cloth, rolls as high as a m

The work begins in "the raw" where the cotton bales are brought in and men with surgical masks covering their nos and mouths rip apart the bales of cotton, feeding them in 1 the mouths of hoppers that shred the cotton fibers and So them apart. Cotton dust and lint fill the air like snow, coating everyone from head to toe.

Carders are next on the line, then spinners and doffers. Almost all the work can be seen in this vast room, the si of an enormous pasture, without interior walls. The rolls of terry cloth slowly unwind behind the backs of the side henmers » passing yard by yard through the women's sewing machines.
grey-streaked, traces of beauty still visible. She works with her face close to a spider web of threads, her hands rapidly guiding them. It is work of intense concentration demanding, exhausting.

A narrow space with a long window looking out on the work floor. Signs are posted: "Give your chair to a spinner; they only have 15 minutes." The mill hands make quick wor of their meal. There is little conversation; they are already too tired to talk. Norma munches on an apple. BONNIE MAE, a cheerful sparrow of a woman from the folding tables, speaks to her.
You just eating an apple for lunch?
I'm dieting.

Well, I gotta keep my strength up. (eats heartily, biting into a thick sandwich) I put this jelly up myself. on Sunday, Roscoe and I put up over sixty quarts of peaches. What'd you do over the weekend, Norma?
Soaked my feet.
Saw you downtown. Your friend drives a big car.
If you'd looked on the motel register, you'd a seen my name there, too.
It's none of my business... Norma turns to look at her mother beside her. The woman's eyes are closed, her head rests back against the tile. Cont.
8 cont.
Momma, you haven't opened your sack. Leona remains motionless.
Momma, don't you want your lunch? Still the woman doesn't answer.
Momma ! Still Leona remains with her eyes closed. Alarmed, Norma shakes her and Leona finally opens her eyes, looking at h daughter blankly.
What is it, Momma? Don't you feel good?
What?

Don't you hear me? Momma! (bends close to her, bawling) Momma, Momma, Momma! Leona doesn't respond. Norma is on her feet instantly. Sh hauls her mother up, grabs her by the arm, and, pulling after her, she runs.
It is a headlong race across the length of the mill, Norm ahead and frantic, her mother in tow.
DR. WATSON is confronted by an agitated, flaring Norma, while Leona sits with her hands calmly folded in her lap.
She didn't hear me} She didn't hear one word I said! She doesn't hear you now!
You know this happens, Norma Rae. It happens all the time. Cont.
10 Cont.
Well, not to my momma!
It'll pass off. It's just temporary.
That makes it all right, huh? She's only deaf for an hour, she's only deaf for two hours, she's only deaf all day!
(mildly) She can get herseif another job.
What other job in this town? "his is the only job.
I'll give her a note. They'll send her home.
(bitterly) Come on, Momma. You're nothing to any of 'em. She takes her mother's arm and shepherds her out.

text: The back of the shotgun house sits in an almost grassless plot. In one corner of the yard a shade tree struggles to live. It is still daylight, and underneath, on a straight backed kitchen chair, Leona Witchard sits quietly. She sits very still, her face tilted toward the meager green above her; she is in a reverie, on the wings of a dream.
Norma is at the sink, washing the dishes, her father Vern towel in hand, dries. Norma, as she works, watches her mother through the open window. She finally calls out to her.
You all right out there? Without turning, Leona responds in her quiet, patient voi Cont.
12 Cont.
OQ Yes. I'm all right.
You'll get all bitten up.
I'm coming in soon. Norma returns to the job at hand. She suddenly wipes her hands briskly on a towel.
I'm gonna let this pot soak.
(mildly) There's one soaking from breakfast.
Well, now it's got company. She goes out.
SG In the sparsely furnished room, two children, CRAIG an MILLIE, sit raptly watching TELEVISION. Norma enters.

as Vernon looms in the doorway.

REUBEN WARSHOVSKY stands on the stoop. He has two large suitcases and is dressed in tennis shoes blue jeans and a T-shirt. Reuben is lean, sharp, full of nervous and intellectual energy; his view of life wavers between the jaundiced and the merry. He is a master of finagle and accommodation; he is purposeful and principle He is fully mobilized always, however calm and easy his manner may be.
Mr. Witchard?
That's right. Vernon Witchard, Who're you?
My name is Reuben Warshovsky.
Warshovsky? What kind of name is that? ,
It's the kind you have to spell for telephone operators and headwaiters.
What do you want?
I'd like to get me a room with a mill family.
What for? We got a hotel with 12 rooms and a motel with 24 rooms.
I want to get to know some mill hands. Close up.
Why is that? Cont.
558 15 Cont.

Mr. Witchard...I got into town about an hour ago, parked my rented car, got out, and, before I could adjust my crotch, the Chief of Police was on me, saying ‘Who are you, I don't know you! and 'what the hell are you doing here?! I told him I was a labor organizer, come to put a union in the 0.P. Henley textile mill, and he said, 'The fuck you are!! gave me a ticket and told me to get my ass elsewhere right quick. Norma has appeared behind her father and listens curiousl
He's dead right. As far as I'm concerned, you're all Communists or agitators or crooks or Jews or all four together. Any town you show up, folks get thrown out of work and get their heads busted.
What .do you make an hour, Mr. Witchard?
Two dollars and eighteen cents!
When did you have your last cost-of-living raise?
I never had that.
With all due respect, Mr. Witchard, with today's inflation, that makes you a shlemiel,.
You calling me some kind of name or other?!
You're underpaid. You're overworked. They're shafting you, right up to your tonsils. You need me. Cont.  558 10 15 cont.1
If you hurry, you can get to the fence before my dog bites you.
What're you telling him that for? We don't have a dog.
(looking at her father) You don't need one. He hefts the heavy suitcases, turns and goes.

The place has never seen better days. It was always none too clean, familiar with the hot-pillow trade and other transients. The rooms have a view of a blacktop parking area and a scummy swimming pool. Norma sits in the small lobby, flipping through the pages of a magazine, ignored by ALSTON PURVIS, the desk clerk. She looks up with some surprise as Reuben enters, by now footsore and weary. He recognizes her.
This is one friendly little town you got here. I've been told to shove off, to piss off, and to git off.
(mildly) This place is okay. Just make sure they spray the room for roaches.
I'm familiar with roaches. goes to the esk) I'd like a room with a view.
You got the back alley or the parking lot. Which? Cont.  ©
11 16 Cont.

(intervening) Give him 207, Alston. You can't hear the drunks in there. . GEORGE BENSON enters. He is a large man, floridly handsom commanding, with an edge of violence just concealed. He walks straight past Norma for the stairs, making only a peremptory beckoning gesture. She tosses aside the magazi and rises to follow.

The SHOWER is HEARD RUNNING from the open bathroom. Norma sits on the edge of the torn-apart bed, fastening her bra; she gets up and pulls on her jeans. Her face is impassive; whatever has transpired in the past hour has left her unmoved. George comes in, a towel wrapped around his middie, his hair still streaming. He combs his hair at the mirror, drops of water spraying.
I'll be back this way next Wednesday. After dinner. I'm having dinner with my wife's folks.
Tonight was the last time, George. He doesn't turn. The. comb simply moves a little more slowly.
You don't say, Norma Rae. Isn't that a surprising turn.
No. It's been coming for some time.

Well, isn't that funny, I didn't notice it. Didn't you get your steak dinner? Didn't you get your box of pralines? Didn't you get your French red wine? Didn't you come three times in a row in that bed over there? Cont.
12 17 Cont.
I wasn't counting.
now turns to ace her) Looks like I don't know what it takes to satisfy you these days.

It just doesn't sit well with me anymore, George. You got your wife, you got your two kids in high school, there's a lot of gossip, I got my two kids... ~ (shrugs) «ee don't know...it just doesn't make me feel good.
(flatly) You're here to make me feel good. ~ He advances on her.
I'm not trotting down here anymore.

Why, you hick. You got dirt under your fingernails, you leave hair in the sink, you pick your teeth with a matchbook -- I've seen you! Why, shit, what are you good for -- to come out of the factory, wash under your armpits, spread your legs for a poke and go home. And you're dumping me! He hits her hard across the mouth; the impact sends her hurtling across the room, slamming against the opposite wall. cont.

She stumbles once or twice in the walkway, pauses to shov her blouse inside her pants. Reuben is standing at the open door to his room as she passes it. He speaks coolly.
I heard a hell of a thump.
That was me, getting thrown across the room.
You better come in. She follows him into his room.
He goes into the bathroom, returns with a washcloth, dumo ice cubes out of his Coke, hands her the icepack. She put it gingerly against her face.
Sit down. You look a little shaken up. She sits. He notes the condition she's in.
I thought everyone down South was Ashley Wilkes. Cont. 558
You lie down with dogs, you get fleas (removes rag and shows him her nose) Does this look like it's broken to you?
No, I don't think so. Want an aspirin?’
No, thanks.
Band-Aic¢
No.
Valium.

Me and men. I ought to learn to say no from the start. But if it wasn't men, I. don't Know what it would be.

She gets up and begins to wander around. He has already established himself; books are stacked and piled everywhe papers litter the desk, clothes are dumped on the bed and hang from the backs of chairs.
You got a lot of books.

Yeah, I'm afraid I'll wake up in a motel room someday with nothing to read but the phone book. Cont.  558 15 20 Cont. She stops at the picture of a girl that has been propped up on the bureau. She studies it.
She's got big eyes.
She's also got a big brain.
What's her name?
Dorothy Finkelstein. She's a hotshot labor lawyer out of Harvard.
She must be your girl friend if you haul her picture around with you.
Well, we sleep together on Sunday mornings and then we read the New York Times. I guess that makes her my girl friend, NORMA’ (holds out her hand) I'm Norma Rae Wilson.
(shaking) Reuben Warshovsky.
Pleased to meet you.
My pleasure.
(pauses I'm sorry about my daddy. He's got a short fuse.
My credentials keep me out of a lot of places. But every once in a while, somebody'll open a door and put me in the best bedroom and treat me like I was a@ cousin. Cont.
16 20 Cont.
That wouldn't be my daddy. (then, abruptly) You a Jew?
Born and bred.
I never met a Jew before. I heard they had horns. He pushes his hair back to show her.
Circumcised, yes. Horns, no.
Far as I can see, you don't look any different from us.
We are.
Yeah? What makes you different?
History.
Hmmmmm... She looks at him thoughtfully a moment. He is a strange bird. -
Well, thanks for the ice. She hands back the washcloth.
Any time.
Christ, I hope not. She goes out.
17 IN FRONT OF THE MOTEL | a1 Vernon sits parked at the wheel of his battered blue Dodge. As Norma comes out into the night, he waves his hand and calls to her.
Over here, honey, She stops short on the pavement, turns and stares a momen exasperation visible. Then she comes to him.
Thought I'd come down and give you a ride home. She merely looks at him.
(slyly) You ain't got any packages.
(flatly) I ain't got any explanations, either.
Come on, sweetheart. Get in.
She slides in beside him, but she is angry and shows him stony profile.
You want a strawberry ice cream cone? It is useless to hold out against him.
Sure. You treat me like I'm twelve anyhow. Why not?
That's my girl. Beaming, he pulls away and drives off.

Norma and her parents and a throng of mill workers surge through the chain link fence toward the looming, dirt- streaked, windowless red brick building which will swallo them all for the day. It is a spiritless mass of people, silently set for their labor, carrying with them the weariness of season after season. There are no swapped greetings; this work exacts a toll in mind and muscle. NORMA AND REUBEN a4 As she goes through the fence, she comes face to face wit Reuben again; his energy is up. He thrusts a leaflet from a large stack under his arm at each man and woman who pas Suddenly, he finds he is handing one to Norma. She scans it quickly.

There's too many big words in here. If I don't understand it, they ain't gonna understand it. She shoves it back at him and is immediately lost in the crowd. He stops his activity and stands there in some puzzlement, reading his own flyer once again.
A bossman, JIMMY JEROME DAVIS, stands in front of her as she is about to enter the building.

In the weaving room, the back of her shirt already wet. TEDDY BOB KEELER, a fellow worker, taps her on the should she looks around; he indicates a BOSSMAN beckoning to her from his office.
I already told him I wouldn't go out to dinner with him. What's he want now?

be surveyed. TOMMY GARDNER waits for Norma behind a d He has the hard look of a hard-living man, used to dealin with hunting dogs and menials. Norma enters and goes on the attack.
Whatever it is, I didn't do it.
Norma, you got the biggest mouth in this mill. Give us longer breaks, give us more smoking time, give us a Kotex machine --
Do it and I'll shut up.
Well, we're gonna do better'n that. We figure the only way to close that mouth is to hand you a promotion. You're rising in the world, honey.
Yeah? How far and for how much?
We're gonna put you on as a spot-checker.
It ain't gonna make me any friends.
It's gonna make you another dollar and a half an hour. She chews it over. It seems hard to digest.

She is on the floor, clipboard in one hand, stopwatch in the other. She has paused behind LUCIUS WHITE, a black man, and is timing him as he rethreads a loom. When he finishes, she clicks her watch, enters a notation on the board, moves on.
She is behind GEORGE HUBBARD, watches as he unstops a spindle. Again, she clicks her watch, marks his time.  el

Finally, she stands behind her father. Vernon works at th bobbins, doing the job he has done ali his life. He pause only an instant to rub the back of his neck, hurries to recover the tempo. He grins at his daughter over his shoulder, Norma is troubled and unhappy.
How'm I doin! little girl?
You better speed it up, Daddy -- if you can.
(protesting) I'm goin' as fast as I can.
They're watching me and they're watching you... The old man grimly bends forward and his hands fly as he pulls bobbins and threads them.

He. stands on the open back porch at a galvanized tub, scrubbing his hands and face. As he dries off, he uses th towel to whack some of the clinging lint from his shirt and his pants. Norma comes out on the porch; she goes to brush the lint which mats his hair, making him look like a white-haired man of eighty. Vernon stiffly pulls away from her.
Well, I suppose you're sore at me.

(wrestles With it) It's more money. I need it for my kids.
Well, I don't need it from my kid. And he walks into the house, his back stiff. Norma stands troubled. She calls out to her children, alm absently.
Craig...Millie...get out of Grandma's marigolds. She sits on the top step, hugs her knees, broods.

Norma Rae and Bonnie Mae sit down again with flushed face

23 37 Cont.
. (to the vendor) QO Two dogs, lotsa relish and no relish. She turns to Reuben.

ELLIS HARPER comes up to the wagon. He is tall, good- looking, fine-boned, educated. When he sees Norma, he stops; there is a sense of constraint between them.

The white church is a bit larger, in somewhat better repair than Chockoyotte. The REVEREND WAYNE HUBBARD, 'though minister to this flock, does its menial as well as its spiritual work, and with hammer and nails is busy mending the lectern as Norma comes in. .
You caught me in my shirtsleeves, Norma,
Reverend.
Maybe we could have some flowers out of your yard for Sunday, Norma. I got spider mite eating up everything. Can I help you with something?
How long have I been coming to this church, Reverend?
Since you were a little girl.
That's right. I accepted Christ when I was six years old. Would you call me a good Christian?
With a lapse or two, I'd say so.
Would you call yourself a good Christian?
That's for the Lord to say.
I want this church for a union meeting next Saturday afternoon. That's blacks and whites, sitting together. He stops his work and puts down his hammer,
This is a house of God. Cont.
That's what I'm waiting to see -- if it is or it isn't.
You're coming close to blasphemy, Norma.

I've come here and I've said that I've sinned and I've done wrong and I'm sorry and I want God to forgive me. Now I want to see what this church stands for. I want to see if you'll stand up in that pulpit and say there should be justice, there should be union, if you're oppressed, fight back, if you're smitten, rise up -- and the Lord'll be on your side. If you don't do that, I say there's nothing in this church that's any good to me and I'll leave it flat.
We'll miss your voice in the choir, Norma.
You'll hear it raised up someplace else. And she turns on her heel and walks out on him.
Norma pulls up to the curb behind Reuben's car, parks and gets out, four black men and one white emerging with her. She says to them:

You all go in and sit down. I'll be right there. Then she turns purposefully and walks directly across the street. NORMA AND DAN PETERS lio Peters stands on the walk to his house, making an elabora ritual of filling a pipe, tamping it down, sucking on it, as he studies the activity in front of him, Cont.
61 110 Cont. His small boy TYLER rocks on a swing on the porch behind him, Norma comes up to the man,

We're holding a meeting at my house, Dane Union business and then lemonade and cookies. Gingersnaps. I'11 roll up the front shade so you can see right in. Washed. my windows Saturday so you shouldn't have ‘any trouble. Norma sails back across the street to her house. AT HER DOOR lil Sonny is waiting for her, perturbed.
You're going too far now, Norma. This here is where we live.
‘How'm I going too far?
Bunch of black men in there... you're gonna get us in a lot of trouble. :
I never had any trouble with black men, Only trouble I ever had in my life was with white men. She goes inside.

Reuben is already present, together. with another handful of mill hands, black and white. Among those who have come are James Brown, Lucius White, Bonnie Mae and Roscoe, Mavis Pruitt. They are seated on the sofa and on wooden chairs lined around in a circle. <A few men stand against the wall, holding their caps in their hands. Cont.  hoy 558
62 112 Cont. There is no sense of being ill at ease; only of gravity, fatigue, need. Reuben speaks.

I remember some of you from the Chockoyotte Church...I did all the talking that day, I'd like you to talk now. There is silence for a moment, HENRY PROUTY, an old man, looks around the circle, clears his throat, .
A man's work should be a man's work -- not a term in jail.
I got a cousin on the chain gang, says I don't work as hard as you do. A work-worn WOMAN smooths the folds in her lap, reluctant to speak, But she does so,
Excuse me for saying this with men folks here, but if I get my menstrual cramps, which come pretty hard, they won't lemme sit down on my job.
They say you gotta keep to your feet unless you bring a note from the doctor. We wouldn't say we was sick if we wasn't.

I look at a brick wall all day. Used to be a window there but they come and bricked it up to give us the feeling we're shut in. We control your soul, brother and sister, for all this period -- and beware! That's what they're saying with that wall. A COUCH SPRING TWANGS and a coil of wire pokes up, causin Louise Pickens to jump to her feet. Norma is apologetic. Cont.
558 “NORMA The kids are jumping on it all the time. (brings a chair) Sit here.
All through the mill they got this cotton dust and lint that fills up the air. (pauses slightly) I got brown lung. Cough all night and my wife doesn't sleep.
My husband Averill died of brown lung two months ago. His children're going to grow up without knowing him. I got all his clothes if someone could use 'em.
Later. Norma and Reuben are alone, She has brewed a pot of coffee. He is.hunched over his cup, dissatisfied.
I'm not getting the message across. Fifteen people out of eleven hundred.
You're an outsider. Down here things take time. This isn't no New York, where you grab a taxi and grab your hat --
They are interrupted by the appearance of a very sleepy Millie in the doorway.
Momma, Craig is wetting the bed.
(as she goes) I told him not to drink Coke before he goes to sleep. Reuben sits @ moment, then rises to foliow her.

He wanders after her, still sipping from his cup. He continues talking to her through the open door to the bathroom, where she kneels and supports a still sleeping Craig on the toilet. A little TINKLING SOUND accompanies their talk.
We've got to get this thing moving. It's bogging down on me.

Buy a jug of corn whiskey and pick me up on Saturday. We'll hit the back roads. (looks down) Finished, honey? Craig nods once and his head falls to his chest. She hoists him off the toilet, pulls up his pajamas, lifts him in her arms.

on the outskirts of town, Saturday leisure for half a dozen men in work clothes from.the mill consists of sitting or squatting on the gallery of the store with pocketknives and chunks of wood. Reuben puts his foot up on the porch while Norma takes an RC Cola out of the ice chest and cools down. “In a gesture calculated to make him one of them, Reuben takes out a penknife, pries open a blade and begins to whittle as he addresses the men in dumb-show. Chips fly off his stick as he becomes evermore impassioned, The men listen impassively. Before he knows it, he has whittled his stick down to a toothpick, which snaps in his hands. Norma laughs.

A baptism is taking place, people standing knee-high in a little creek. A virginal girl in a white robe, frightened and transported, is tipped backward and submerged. She is lifted, hair streaming, gasping, drenched. A hand reaches INTO the SHOT --
-- As Norma leans forward to press a blue union card into the girl's outflung hand. Cont.

text: Reuben sets himself a little grimly, reaches around his neck to remove the chain with the large Mogen Navid on it, and tucks in manfully as Norma distributes leaflets to the men clustered around.

A mill worker keeps chickens in a roost and a single dairy cowe As Reuben stands in close and serious talk with the man, the cow wanders up. Reuben puts a hand on its rump and shoves it -- the cow bellows, wheels and shits as it lumbers away -- and Reuben is splattered from chin to boots. Norma offers a laconic comment.

It's only grass and water, Reuben... AT A SWIMMING HOLE lel A little river running through sand and clay, the grass spotted with blue and white daisies, sheltered by a row of sedge. The sun is high, the air still, and Reuben is in the water, rolling and snorting, naked, content.
Norma is downstream a little on the bank, vigorously scrubbing his soiled clothes. She looks up at him.
This is where we used to swim when we were kids. We'd hookey off from school, come down here, shuck our clothes and jump in,
The only water I ever saw when I was a kid was when we opened a fire hydrant on 110th Street with a monkey wrench, He floats on his back, very much at peace with the world.
Ahh...this is the life, Cont.
66 122 Cont.
It's just a mudhole.
It's cooling off my mosquito bites.
She wrings out the wet jeans and then spreads them on a rock,
That's as clean as they're gonna get. . Then she leans back on her heels, wipes the sweat from he face.
God, it's hot...I'm coming in. She gets up and begins to shed her clothes matter-of-fact
He swims about lazily, enjoying himself, When he turns again, Norma is in the water near him.
They tread water in place, hardly rippling the surface, quiet, cooling down.
There used to be a farmer around here with a B-B gun. I hope he's moved.
There's something flicking around my toes.
Minnows, They won't hurt you, (grins a little) You're sure a fish out of water down here, aren't you? Cont.  558 67 125 Cont.
It's not exactly my native habitat.
What would you do at home on a day like this?
Play handball at the YMHA. Go ' see Aida at the Met. Eat Chinese. Get in a poker game. Hit the sack.
I've been two places in my life. Millageville and Piston.
New York's a great town. Got a great zoo, jazz joints, terrific food, theater, beautiful women...
You're homesick, Reuben.

Yeah. (pauses) You get up on @ fall morning, look out over the park, the tops of the trees are red. You see a pretty girl with a long scarf tied around her neck, long legs, long hair, You know before the day's over, you're going to meet that girl. About five o'clock, when everybody starts rushing for home, when the streets are jammed, you're turning into an Irish bar, and she'll be there. You'll sit ata little table with your knees touching, drinking an over-priced martini, loquacious, tumescent, terrific. Then you eat a garlicky Italian dinner, get hustled on Madison Avenue for a buck, kiss her good night and lose her phone number,.-eNew York, What a townec. Cont.  68 125 Cent
I'll never get there,
Why not?
I was born poor, I'll stay poor, I'll probably die poor. She submerges, reappears, her hair streaming; she brushes it back from her eyes.
You got a skinny build.
Yeah.
Sonny works out with weights.
I tried that. Dropped 'em and broke my foot.

Well, you don't have to worry. You got a head on you, and you use it. She turns and climbs out of the water, picks up her shirt acd begins toweling off. He follows. They stand sice ty side, naked, backs to the CAMERA, drying themselves.

Sonny, in bed, groans and wakes to the SOUND of his wifs VOICE, coming from the kitchen. He rears up on an elbow, squints with one eye at the bedside clock -~ it is past eleven. He is irritated at not finding her beside him -- suddenly he throws back the covers and heads for her.
Norma is at the phone, a long checklist of names on aj, 4 beside, most of them already crossed off. She is wearing glasses, a baggy old. sweater, a pencil in her disordered hair. cont.
69 127 Cont.

«eeSure, I know why we got @ bad connection -- they probably got a tap on my phone. Hey, youl You listening? This is - Norma Rae Webster, talking union to Henry Willis. Sonny, rumpled, aggrieved, wearing shorts, appears in the doorway and stands, watching his wife.

I'm on tonight and every night, no commercials, same old story, union, union, union, Tell your bossman to tape me and you can go on home to your wife and kids. (then) Henry, you still there? The line BUZZES in her ear, the connection broken.
Damn! She hangs up angrily, sits fuming a moment, then yanks ou the pencil, puts a question mark after Henry's name, fina becomes aware of her husband: in the doorway.
as Sonny speaks shortly.
You ain't getting any sleep and I ain't getting any sleep and we both gotta go ‘to work in the morning.
I got a hundred names to call here.
That gonna go on our phone pill?
It'll come out of my paycheck, how's that?
He doesn't answer, pads past her to the refrigerator, pours a glass of cold milk, takes a mouthful, makes a face, sloshes the rest into the sink,
This milk's sour.
I didn't get to the market.
(goading) . You didn't get to the market and you didn't get to the washing and you didn't get to the kids and you didn't get to me.
(with icy calm) Is that right?
(raging on) We're eating them frozen TV dinners, the kids are going around in dirty jeans, and I'm going without altogether!
Norma pushes back from the table, making a very large show of it,

Okay. You want cooking? You got cooking. There is a tremendous clatter as she yanks open cupboard doors and pots tumble out in every direction, strewn by the fury of her gesture. She slams one on the stove, grab a hunk of meat and some cabbage from the refrigerator, throws the meat into the pot, adds water, whacks the cabb in half, tosses that in as well, bangs the lid on top of Cont.
558 71 130 Cont. She whirls on Sonny again.
You want laundry? You got laundry.
She opens a bin stuffed to the brim with dirty clothes. She hauls out a huge armload, dumps it in the sink, runs the tap water, pours liquid soap over it. She faces Sonny. once more,

You want ironing? You got ironing! She snatches up a shirt out of a basket of unironed clothes, pulls open a cupboard door, wrestles out the ironing board, kicks it vehemently into an upright positi grabs an iron, jams it into a plug. She spreads out the shirt, spits on her finger and tests the iron's heat, begins making furious swipes. Over her shoulder she hurls a final question at Sonny:
You wanna make love? Get behind me and lift my skirt and we'll make lovel
as Sonny stands looking at her, half-admiring, certainly defeated.
Norma, Norma...
During break time, Norma passes among the mill hands with a sheaf of leaflets, handing them out. She comes suddenly face-to-face with her father. Cont.
72 133 Cont.
Well, I don't bump into you much these days.
Are you all right, Daddy?
About the same.
You color's bad. Have you been drinking?
Oh, I take a-thimbleful or so.
It's not good for you.
What's the difference, honey? I'm beginning to wonder when I lie down if I'm gonna get up.
Don't talk old to me, I don't like it. She embraces him fiercely, touched by a strange forebodin
One of these nights I'm gonna come by and take you to a grand dinner... She nods and leaves him, weaving through the crowd of mill hands until she is out of sight.  558 73

It is late. Reuben sits with his legs on the desk, studyi briefs; Norma is at a typewriter at another desk, pecking away with two fingers. She pauses to erase, pecks again, makes another mistake, erases again, pulls the paper out, crumples it up and throws it down. She yawns widely.
(without looking up) James,
He went home an hour ago. He grunts, goes back to his reading.
I oughta be going home. She gets up, rubs her back, goes to the open window, gets deep breath of air.
As she turns back, she notes that a new picture of Dorothy Finkelstein has arrived. She goes to it idly.
How's Dorothy? .
(absorbed in his reading) Fine.
I see you got another picture.
My mother sent it.
I bet she gets along with your mother. He finally looks up.
Are you kidding? My mother loves her. She's a lawyer, she's Jewish, she's a lefto, and she's a great cook. What the hell else could she want? Cont.
135 Cont. She puts the picture down, stares at it a moment longer. seems a little wistful.
How'd she get to be so smart?

Books. xX He rummages in one of half a dozen brown paper bags, look for food, comes up with a banana, peels it, eats it voraciously. x Another bag yields a final can of beer. He pulls the tab, holds it out while it foams, drinks deeply.

Dinner. A banana and beer. (goes back to the subject) Books! You read 'em under the covers with a flashlight, you read 'em down in the subway, you put ‘em in your lunch pail, you take 'em to the bathroom and read 'em on the toilet. ‘It's the only way up -- it's the only way out. (burps and thumps his chest) Excuse me.
She wanders past the row of books he has strewn about, pi one up at random.
Who's Dylan Thomas?
A poet, a drunk, a genius. Cont.
~136 Cont.
What does he write about?
Love, sex, death, and other matters of consequence.
Is he hard to read?
Yeah.
Then why should I bother?
‘Cause he's got something to say. xX
I'll try him. Hell, there's nothing but reruns on television.
Don't eat while you reads I can't stand egg yolk on my pooks. She stands riffling through the pages.

In the thundering weave section, amidst the DIN and the flying lint, a spot-checker stops behind Vernon, working down a row of pumping bobbins. The man shakes his shoulde shouts in his ear, indicating that he should speed up. Vernon's hands fly, he works at top speed; sweating with exertion.
Reuben opens the door to the Chockoyotte Church and enter

It is empty. A kitten has gotten in and picks its way alo the altar, pausing to lift its head and stare at the intruder. Baffled, Reuben sits down in a pew at the back and waits. cause, a man, and a cat.  76
Reuben pulls up in front of a ramshackle home, its paint worn down to grey board, a step or two broken, the porch listing, an abandoned mattress falling apart in the yard. He knocks.
as Warren Latting opens the door, The man is still work stained from his day at the mill, hollow-eyed, exhausted.
Nobody showed at the meeting today. What's going on?

They got us on a stretch-out. Put us on a three-day week. Twice as much work and half the pay. On accout of you. You just stand there a minute. ANOTHER ANGLE 14e He disappears, leaving Reuben to cool his heels on the pe In a moment he is back with a steaming pot in his hand. H lifts the lid.

There's six turnips and two quarts of water in there, Supper for seven people. Go sell your union someplace else, He kicks the door shut in Reuben's face, Reuben explodes; the street fighter in him comes out. He pounds on the dec with his fist until it threatens to give away on its rott hinges and shouts at the top of his voice,
Goddamn it, Warren, don't slam the fucking door on me! I'm trying to get you power!
In the house on either side, startled faces appear at the windows to glimpse the disturber of the peace.

Reuben is pawing through a large stack of the blue cards hard won. Norma, James Brown and Lucius White watch him. is still on the nervous edge of energy, tense, temperish, combative. Cont.  © 77 . 144 cont.
Somebody gets the measles, everybody gets the measles.
Maybe they was too tired to come, Everybody's pretty beat out, working so hard.
You can include me!
While we been planning, they been planning. This stretch- out's just the first of what they can hit us with.
They got away from us, we gotta get 'em back, Walk in a bunch. Show 'em we're solid. (gently) Come on, Reuben, But Reuben sits with his head in his hands. Norma needles him,
What's the matter, Reuben? You running out of gas?
I need to go to a concert, I need an Italian movie. I need some chopped herring.
I could try making you some of that chicken soup and matza dumplings...
(crossly) Balls! Balls!
He spreads the cards out.
All right. Let's get a count on how many we got. Everybody grab a handful. “558 Cont.
558 78 145 Cont. They each pick up a group of cards. Norma looks at the fi one strangely.
Who's this Billy Joe Hawkins? I never heard of him. James has found one that puzzles him.
I got Lindsay Perkins here. He died last year.
Lucius has discovered an odd one.
Blayden. He moved his family 1 to Jackson...
Josh Little, Jr. There ain't no Josh ‘ittle, Jr. in that 5 factory... Reuben begins flipping cards, barking out names.
Ab Harris, Herman Burk, Ardean Miller, Frank Dorn, Dan Decker, Wiley Bains... He looks up at the others. James Brown shakes his head emphatically.
No, sir. Those fellows don't work at our plant.
Those names are dummies. (pauses) Somebody wants you to think you got more members than you got.

A stressful moment follows, in which Reuben looks around thoughtfully at his three helpers, ‘Now he has to face th possibility that he has been infiltrated. Outside there is a SQUEAL of BRAKES, a car skidding to a  0 558 79

Wayne Billings swings jauntily out of a station wagon tha has been turned into a union float: it is plastered with banners and pennants » U.S. flags front and back and a la sign on top saying, "I'M FOR TWUA."
As Wayne enters, he finds four impassive faces regarding coolly. He drops an impressive-looking batch of cards dow on the desk.
Here's some more bodies for you. Reuben flips one over to James, who glances at it briefly
Bodies is right, This one's been in the boneyard for ten years.
Reuben rises. There is suddenly an impending sense of violence in the closely-packed little room,

I don't want to make a mess of you here, because I eat and sleep here. He throws the false cards into his face. Wayne's mouth cp and closes, opens and closes again. He looks from one tc other; all four are clenched against him. He suddenly gce beserk, He stomps out.

He runs to the station wagon, a bull on a rampage, strips huge sign off the’ top and starts tearing it violently to pieces. He rips off the banners, the pennants, the signs, the flags, flinging them onto the blacktop, stomping on t grinding them under his heels, flailing the wooden poles held them against the side of the car until they splinter Then he reaches through the window into the glove compart snatches up something, and comes running back,
Reuben and the others have stepped into the open doorway watch him. Hysterical, the man charges up at him, scrabbl through a box of cartridges, grabs a bullet and rams it i Reuben's belly.
Reuben looks down at the gleaming copper cartridge, then up at Wayne's face, trembling with the ague of uncontroll Lage.

Man, you can't do it that way. What you've got to do is get a gun, put that thing in a chamber, point it at a guy, and pull the trigger. That's how you do it. ) Wayne's head is shaking from side to side; otherwise, he paralyzed. Reuben takes the bullet from his hand, lifts t hand, opens the palm, holds the bullet suspended above it then drops it in.
Vernon works at an accelerated clip, the bobbins reeling yarn. He is like a man at stoop labor, bending, rising, bending, rising.
He suddenly sits down on the floor, his eyes closed. The bobbins keep jerking up and down before him, . Jimmy Jerome Davis comes over, puts his face down close s he can hear,
I don't feel too good. Like to go lie down.
You got a break coming up in fifteen minutes, Vernon.
I need to go now,
You hold on, Vernon. Your preak's coming up. He pats Vernon on the back and walks on,
He tries to resume work and then falls into the bobbins. They continue to pump up and down around his inert body.

Like everything else in Millageville, the graveyard is ha harsh, graves wrested out of rocky soil. People who have spent their lives in unremitting work come to a stony res place here, Norma, Leona, the children, Sonny, uncomfortable in a dar suit, stand by the open grave as the pine box is lowered. Reuben and a group of mill hands, friends of Vernon's, st at a respectful distance.

A truck lumbers past the mourners, backs up to the open g The grave diggers step out of the way. The tailgate drops down; white sand sifts down onto the pine box in a steady stream, slowly covering it. Norma turns to her mother.
I just couldn't stand the thought of dirt going over him like that. The white sand now completely covers the coffin.

There is a sudden movement among the factory workers. As the grave is closed, a few of them move toward Norma. They pay their last respects to Vernon Witchard by placin in Norma's hand a signed blue union card.
She holds three or four cards in her hand and turns to lo at Reuben,
(harshly) - Somebody's gotta die to get ‘em, .
Two men enter the tiny lobby. AL LONDON and SAM DAKIN are both middle-aged, matter-of-fact, tough, seasoned. They g past the desk clerk without a word, turn down the hall,
They stride through the dark corridor, looking at room numbers, They find the number they want, knock. There is no answer. They throw the door open and move in,
oO 558
82 162 It is late and Norma, exhausted, has thrown clutter off t bed, curled up on it and fallen into a deep sleep.
163 She awakens with a start to find two strangers standing i the doorway and looking down at her. Norma stands.
Who are you looking for? The two men are present on business and have no time for amenities.
Warshovsky around?
He's at the printer's,
Pretty late for the printer's...
Reuben keeps him working late.
We'll talk to you 'til he gets back. You're Norma Rae, aren't you? :
(sensing hostility) I'm Missus Webster.
We're from the union. National headquarters, (points to the other man) Al London, And I'm Sam Dakin.
As long as you're here, I'll give you my shopping list. We need envelopes, we need typing paper, we need stamps, we. need a loudspeaker, we could use a couple more typewriters that don't stick. cont.
83 163 Cont.
Yo We're not in office supplies, Cy Missus Webster. Sat
You're not around much, either.
as Reuben walks in. If he is surprised to see the men, he doesn't show it. They shake hands all around.
How are you, Sam? You've gotten fat.
Yeah, I put on a couple of pounds.
How are you, Al?
Lousy, I got a cold, There is an awkward pause,
What brings you?
You're not getting up much of @ head of steam, Reuben.
You've had my reports, You know what I'm up against.
We're worried,
That makes three of us.
This is a small Baptist Southern town. We have to keep our noses very clean. 2 Cont. 558  558 84 164 cont.
(reacting to the pressure ) You see any snot on mine?
Maybe Missus Webster would like to leave?
as Norma turns to go, Reuben raises a hand. She stops in her tracks.
Why should she leave?
This concerns her, I'm trying to make it easy for her.
(irritably) Come on, come on, it's late. What is it?

The company wants us to look bad. They're going to use everything they can to make us look bad. You know, these mill hands go to church every Sunday, and she's talking union to 'em, (pauses slightly) They say she was in a porno movie, with a member of the local police department, Very explicit.
Show it to me. Run it for me,
There doesn't have to be a movie if there's talk that there is one. This lady has had an illegitimate child. She's slept around. She takes naps on your bed late at night. Cont.  558 85 165 Cont.

What the fuck is this? Are we in the character assassination business or are we in the union business? All of a sudden, after I've put in an eighteen hour day, I got the legion of decency on my hands! She's been breaking her ass for this organization. She doesn't see her kids, she doesn't have time to take a bath! What the fuck - do I care if she's got round heels? Is this the Catholic Church?...Are we going to canonize her? What the shit is this!
This is your show, Reuben...but maybe she ought to go.
Make it stick. If you can't, get out of here. (throws open the door) Get out of here anyway.
(to Norma) I'm sorry about this, Mrs. Webster, It's part of my job -- but I could do without it. He motions to London. The two men leave.
Norma and Reuben are alone in the room. She is grateful f his defense but aware of the gravity of the situation. Neither speaks a moment.
I wouldn't hurt the union, If you want me to quit, I will.
(irritably) How come you were sleeping? I asked you to type those letters, She goes to the typewriter, rubbing a sore spot in her ba He jams a cigar in his mouth and goes back to his work.

Norma gets out of her car, hauling a bag of groceries wit her. Her mother is in a chair on the front porch, solitar motionless, the evening paper unread across her lap. A garden hose drips water on her plants in coffee cans li the porch. Norma hails her as she crosses the lawn,
I brought you laundry soap, I brought you bread, I brought you some ground chuck -- it was on sale,
Sit down, you look perspired. With a groan, Norma puts the bag down, sits on the top st at her mother's feet.
I don't know why those housewives have to shop just when we get off our shift.
I've told you, you don't have to market for me. I can go over to the store after supper, when it's cool, and get my few little things.
If I didn't market, you wouldn't eat anything. You'd eat crackers and drink coffee. Anyway -- it gives me a chance to come and sit down and talk to you. (looks up at her) Momma, you been crying?

I was thinking of your daddy. (pauses ) I was thinking how short a person's life is. You gotta hurry to catch your goals, Don't let the days pass...your daddy was a young man, then he was an old one. I wonder -- did he leave things undone? Did he leave things unsaid? Cont.
87 167 Cont. LEONA (Cont.) (looks at her daughter) Child, if there's something you want, don't wait all the way down the line to get it.
Was there something you wanted you didn't get?
If there was, I've forgotten it.
Momma, wouldn't you like to come and stay with me? The kids are around, they make a lot of noise, it's cheerful.
I'm used to this house,
(worried) What if you fall down the steps? What if you fall in the bathtub? What if something happens to you?
Then it will. Norma suddenly reaches for her mother's hand and kisses i
Now what was that for?
For you -- and for me, (rises) I'm going in and boil you an ‘egg.
